clues.clue: (1) If X, then Y. (2) X. Therefore Y.
Rewriting prose into explicit premises and a conclusion is called this.
clues.solution: What is formalizing (or reconstructing) an argument?

clues.clue: Giving an opponent’s view its strongest reading is known as this dialectical norm.
clues.solution: What is the Principle of Charity?

clues.clue: The soundness of an argument has these two components.
clues.solution: What are validity and true premises?

clues.clue: The three strategies for responding to objections (as well as next steps in a dialectic).
clues.solution: What are incorrect supposition, accommodate, and partners-in-crime?

clues.clue: Descartes’ Method of Doubt reaches its highest form via this sinister scenario.
In Med. 2: The two truths Descartes believes he can be certain of, even under extreme doubt.
clues.solution: What are 'I exist' and 'I exist as a thinking thing'?

clues.clue: In Enquiry sec. 4, Hume argues we lack a rational justification for this everyday practice that projects past regularities into the future.
Hume divides all truths into thse two categories.
clues.solution: What are 'Relations of Ideas' and 'Matters of Fact'.

clues.clue: Moore claims that he can know this without being able to prove it.
clues.solution: What is 'Here is one hand (and here's another)'?

clues.clue: In the traditional analysis of knowledge, 'JTB' stands for this
In Gettier's first case, Smith and Jones are in competition for this.
The number of coins Smith didn't realize were in his pocket.
In Gettier's second case, Smith has good evidence that 'Jones owns a Ford,' but the truth of his belief comes from Brown's location in this city.
Gettier’s counterexamples show the JTB analysis of knowledge cannot be true because it lacks this logical property.
Descartes argues the mind and body are distinct because the mind has these properties essentially.
A classic objection: if the mind has no physical properties, this kind of two-way influence seems mysterious.
Armstrong argues for this overarching view about what mental states are.
Armstrong targets this rival view that analyzes mental states as mere patterns of outward behavior.
The contemporary name for the view that mental states are whatever causes behavior.
The knowledge argument challenges this theory.
What Jackson says Mary is lacking in the black-and-white room.
clues.solution: What is knowing what it's like (knowledge)?

clues.clue: What Lewis says Mary learned, instead of a new fact.
The term Jackson and Lewis use for the 'what it's like' aspect of conscious experience.
Jackson insists the Knowledge Arguent is not about this mental ability.
The theory that says free will and determinism can coexist.
What Frankfurt is most specifically trying to show with the Jones-4 case.
clues.solution: What is 'the Principle of Alternate Possibilities is false'?

clues.clue: The Principle of Alternate Possibilities says this.
clues.solution: What is 'A person is morally responsible only if they could have done otherwise'?

clues.clue: Van Inwagen's No Choice Principle says this.
clues.solution: What is: If no one has any choice about 'if p, then q' and no one has any choice about 'p', then no one has any choice about 'q'?

clues.clue: Nelkin's Rational Abilities View says that one needs the ability to do otherwise only if one meets this condition.
clues.solution: What is 'failing to respond to the right reasons'?

clues.clue: The name of the Trolley Driver.
The name of the bystander who pushes the large man off the bridge.
The name of the tourist who is offered the role of executioner in Graham's 'Swedes' case.
The name of the President who blows up Worcester to save New York.
The name of the diagnostician who can save five by initiaing a peculiar physiological process resuling in the death of one.
The author who considered the objection that their proof assumes the truth of its conclusion.
The author who objected to Agent Causation by saying it solves a mystery with another mystery.
Nelkin introduces the Rosa case in reply to the charge that her view has this morally dubious property.
In Enquiry 7.1 Hume responds to the objection that we get our idea of causal powers from this familiar source.
clues.solution: What is the operation of the will (volition)?

clues.clue: Jackson responds to Lewis's Ability Reply by imagining that Mary becomes skeptical about the existence of this.
Lewis introduces the concept of 'knowing what it's like' using this antipodean condiment.
Descartes claims that objects are better known by the understanding than the senses in an argument featuring this substance.
The nefarious character from Frankfurt's Jones-4 case.
Armstrong considers an objection to the idea that mental states cause behavior built around the example of this.
clues.solution: What is zoning out while driving?

clues.clue: To illustrate the Mystery of Indeterminism, van Inwagen introduces Jane, who is deciding whether to do this.
clues.solution: What is tell the truth (or stay silent)?

clues.clue: In Descartes’s Med. 6, what specifically is his conclusion about the relationship between mind and body?
clues.solution: What is that they are distinct substances (things)?

clues.clue: This disposessed member of the European peerage was an early proponent of the causal interaction objection to Descartes.
clues.solution: Who is Princess Elisabeth of Bohemia?

clues.clue: Descartes speculated that the site of mind-body causal interaction was this structure in the brain.
Where Ryle thought dispositions were merely facts about how things tend to behave, Armstrong thinks they are this.
clues.solution: What are inner states of things (that explain behavior)?

clues.clue: Lewis supports his Ability Reply to Jackson by likening the mind to this household object.
Because all truths of reasoning are suspect under the demon test, we said Descartes may not be first-personally licensed to conclude this.
clues.solution: What is 'I exist (as a thinking thing)'?

clues.clue: Although the premise does differ from the conclusion, we noted Moore's proof may still be illegitimate if it does this.
clues.solution: What is Begs the Question (premises assume conclusion)?

clues.clue: For Descartes to play the 'partners in crime' strategy against the interaction objection, he would need to say this.
clues.solution: What is 'No theory of mind has an adequate answer to the problem of mental causation (mind-body interaction)'?

clues.clue: If Armstrong commits to his claim that consciousness is a self-scanning mechanism of the brain, he may be giving up on this essential feature of his theory.
clues.solution: What is Functionalism (mental states are the causes of behavior)?

clues.clue: Frankfurt's Jones-4 case may not constitute a good argument for Compatibilism because it appears to assume this.
clues.solution: What is 'Jones could have done otherwise in making the decision to act'?

clues.clue: People who have the intuition that free will is an illusion are called this.
The example evaluation of the Frame the Drifter argument makes this judgment about the premise that 'aggregate happiness is the only thing that matters morally'.
Philosophers who defend the idea that the operation of the mind is the foundation of knowledge (rather than the senses) are known as this.
According to survey data from the University of Michigan and elsewhere, 80% of people agree with this vehicular intuition.
clues.solution: What is 'It's permissible for a bystander to turn the trolley'?

clues.clue: Native speakers of East Asian languages have a stronger tendency than others to disagree with Gettier about this intuition.
clues.solution: What is 'That Smith doesn't have knowledge'?

final.clue: This is one of the two assumptions required to make Gettier's counterexamples work.
final.solution: What is 'you can be justified in believing something false' / 'if you're justified in P, and P implies Q, then you're justified in Q'?
